For points P, Q, R, and S on a line in a 2-dimensional Euclidean space with an inner product, if the angle between PQ and QR is of the same sign as the angle between QR and RS, then the points lie on the same line.

type:
‚àÄ {V : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ‚Ñù V] [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]
  [inst_3 : NormedAddTorsor V P] [hd2 : Fact (FiniteDimensional.finrank ‚Ñù V = 2)] [inst_4 : Module.Oriented ‚Ñù V (Fin 2)]
  {p‚ÇÅ p‚ÇÇ p‚ÇÉ : P} (p‚ÇÑ : P),
  Sbtw ‚Ñù p‚ÇÅ p‚ÇÇ p‚ÇÉ ‚Üí (EuclideanGeometry.oangle p‚ÇÅ p‚ÇÑ p‚ÇÇ).sign = (EuclideanGeometry.oangle p‚ÇÇ p‚ÇÑ p‚ÇÉ).sign
name: Sbtw.oangle_sign_eq
docString: For points P, Q, R, and S on a line in a 2-dimensional Euclidean space with an inner product, if the angle between PQ and QR is of the same sign as the angle between QR and RS, then the points lie on the same line.

This theorem, from the field of Euclidean geometry, states that for any points `p‚ÇÅ`, `p‚ÇÇ`, and `p‚ÇÉ` in a two-dimensional real inner product space with a given orientation, if the oriented angle `p‚ÇÅ p‚ÇÇ p‚ÇÉ` is equal to œÄ/2 (which corresponds to a right angle), then the ratio of the distance from `p‚ÇÅ` to `p‚ÇÇ` to the cosine of the oriented angle `p‚ÇÉ p‚ÇÅ p‚ÇÇ` is equal to the distance from `p‚ÇÅ` to `p‚ÇÉ`. This corresponds to the geometric property of a right-angled triangle where the length of a side adjacent to an angle, divided by the cosine of that angle, equals the length of the hypotenuse.

type:
‚àÄ {V : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ‚Ñù V] [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]
  [inst_3 : NormedAddTorsor V P] [hd2 : Fact (FiniteDimensional.finrank ‚Ñù V = 2)] [inst_4 : Module.Oriented ‚Ñù V (Fin 2)]
  {p‚ÇÅ p‚ÇÇ p‚ÇÉ : P},
  EuclideanGeometry.oangle p‚ÇÅ p‚ÇÇ p‚ÇÉ = ‚Üë(Real.pi / 2) ‚Üí dist p‚ÇÅ p‚ÇÇ / (EuclideanGeometry.oangle p‚ÇÉ p‚ÇÅ p‚ÇÇ).cos = dist p‚ÇÅ p‚ÇÉ
name: EuclideanGeometry.dist_div_cos_oangle_left_of_oangle_eq_pi_div_two
docString: This theorem, from the field of Euclidean geometry, states that for any points `p‚ÇÅ`, `p‚ÇÇ`, and `p‚ÇÉ` in a two-dimensional real inner product space with a given orientation, if the oriented angle `p‚ÇÅ p‚ÇÇ p‚ÇÉ` is equal to œÄ/2 (which corresponds to a right angle), then the ratio of the distance from `p‚ÇÅ` to `p‚ÇÇ` to the cosine of the oriented angle `p‚ÇÉ p‚ÇÅ p‚ÇÇ` is equal to the distance from `p‚ÇÅ` to `p‚ÇÉ`. This corresponds to the geometric property of a right-angled triangle where the length of a side adjacent to an angle, divided by the cosine of that angle, equals the length of the hypotenuse.

For any positive integers m, n, and k, the quotient of n by k is equal to the quotient of the product of m and n by the product of m and k. In other words, (m * n) / (m * k) = n / k.

type: ‚àÄ {m : ‚Ñï} (n k : ‚Ñï), 0 < m ‚Üí m * n / (m * k) = n / k
name: Nat.mul_div_mul_left
docString: For any positive integers m, n, and k, the quotient of n by k is equal to the quotient of the product of m and n by the product of m and k. In other words, (m * n) / (m * k) = n / k.

This theorem states that in a right-angled triangle, the length of a side (the distance between points p‚ÇÉ and p‚ÇÇ) divided by the tangent of the angle opposite to that side (the angle at p‚ÇÉ formed by points p‚ÇÉ, p‚ÇÅ, and p‚ÇÇ) equals the length of the adjacent side (the distance between points p‚ÇÅ and p‚ÇÇ). This is under the conditions that we are working in a 2-dimensional real inner product space, which has a specified orientation.

type:
‚àÄ {V : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ‚Ñù V] [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]
  [inst_3 : NormedAddTorsor V P] [hd2 : Fact (FiniteDimensional.finrank ‚Ñù V = 2)] [inst_4 : Module.Oriented ‚Ñù V (Fin 2)]
  {p‚ÇÅ p‚ÇÇ p‚ÇÉ : P},
  EuclideanGeometry.oangle p‚ÇÅ p‚ÇÇ p‚ÇÉ = ‚Üë(Real.pi / 2) ‚Üí dist p‚ÇÉ p‚ÇÇ / (EuclideanGeometry.oangle p‚ÇÉ p‚ÇÅ p‚ÇÇ).tan = dist p‚ÇÅ p‚ÇÇ
name: EuclideanGeometry.dist_div_tan_oangle_left_of_oangle_eq_pi_div_two
docString: This theorem states that in a right-angled triangle, the length of a side (the distance between points p‚ÇÉ and p‚ÇÇ) divided by the tangent of the angle opposite to that side (the angle at p‚ÇÉ formed by points p‚ÇÉ, p‚ÇÅ, and p‚ÇÇ) equals the length of the adjacent side (the distance between points p‚ÇÅ and p‚ÇÇ). This is under the conditions that we are working in a 2-dimensional real inner product space, which has a specified orientation.

In a tetrahedron with vertices `x`, `y`, `p`, `q`, any segment `[u, v]` joining the opposite
edges `[x, p]` and `[y, q]` passes through any triangle of vertices `p`, `q`, `z` where
`z ‚àà [x, y]`.

Given a triangle, and a fourth point such that twice the angle between two points of the
triangle at that fourth point equals twice the third angle of the triangle, the fourth point
lies in the circumsphere of the triangle.

type:
‚àÄ {V : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ‚Ñù V] [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]
  [inst_3 : NormedAddTorsor V P] [hd2 : Fact (FiniteDimensional.finrank ‚Ñù V = 2)] [inst_4 : Module.Oriented ‚Ñù V (Fin 2)]
  {t : Affine.Triangle ‚Ñù P} {p : P} {i‚ÇÅ i‚ÇÇ i‚ÇÉ : Fin 3},
  i‚ÇÅ ‚â† i‚ÇÇ ‚Üí
    i‚ÇÅ ‚â† i‚ÇÉ ‚Üí
      i‚ÇÇ ‚â† i‚ÇÉ ‚Üí
        2 ‚Ä¢ EuclideanGeometry.oangle (Affine.Simplex.points t i‚ÇÅ) p (Affine.Simplex.points t i‚ÇÉ) =
            2 ‚Ä¢
              EuclideanGeometry.oangle (Affine.Simplex.points t i‚ÇÅ) (Affine.Simplex.points t i‚ÇÇ)
                (Affine.Simplex.points t i‚ÇÉ) ‚Üí
          p ‚àà Affine.Simplex.circumsphere t
name: Affine.Triangle.mem_circumsphere_of_two_zsmul_oangle_eq
docString:
Given a triangle, and a fourth point such that twice the angle between two points of the
triangle at that fourth point equals twice the third angle of the triangle, the fourth point
lies in the circumsphere of the triangle.
